awd_titl_txt: REU Site: ICompBio - Engaging Undergraduates in Interdisciplinary Computing for Biological Research
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga, located in Chattanooga, TN, will support the training of 10 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2019 to 2021. This REU focuses on interdisciplinary computational biology (iCompBio) training for college sophomores and juniors in STEM majors. The student application includes an application form, transcripts, a personal statement, a resume, and 2 letters of recommendations. Applications will be reviewed by a team of faculty research mentors.  Students will learn various computational methods and apply them to address biological questions. Each student will be jointly mentored by a computer science mentor and a biology mentor. A one-week computing bootcamp will be provided to teach students essential data science using R, and advanced data processing and deep learning methods using Python. The biological research topics include aging and longevity, ecological networks, biodiversity, microbial pathway evolution, aquatic ecology, environment sustainability, nanoparticle fertilizers, field ecology, herbarium digitization, protein structures, and cell membrane structures. The computing training includes coding, modeling, simulation, deep learning neural networks, computer vision, parallel computing, statistics, data visualization, and mobile App development.  Students will also go through training in ethics and responsible conduct for research. 
 
It is anticipated that a total of 30 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in iCompBio.  Students will learn how to conduct reproducible computational research, and will make their coding projects publicly available through GitHub. Students will also be encouraged to present their research results in scientific meetings.  
 
A common web-based assessment tool, SALG URSSA, used by all REU Site programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available at http://utc.edu/icompbio or by contacting the PI (Dr. Hong Qin at hong-qin@utc.edu ) or the co-PI (Dr. Soubantika Palchoudhury at soubantika-palchoudhury@utc.edu).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
From 2019 to 2023, the iCompBio Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) program has been instrumental in advancing computational biology among undergraduate students from diverse backgrounds, with over 50 students benefiting from its comprehensive training. The program's success is attributed to its commitment to hands-on research experiences, fostering a collaborative environment, and enhancing participants' academic and research capabilities.

 

Initiated in 2019, the iCompBio REU program embarked on an ambitious mission to immerse undergraduates in the interdisciplinary realm of computational biology. Confronted with the global COVID-19 pandemic in the following two years, the program demonstrated remarkable adaptability, hosting dozens of students in a vibrant and diverse setting amidst challenging conditions. This period was marked by a concerted effort to integrate students from varied academic backgrounds into a cohesive research community, with their achievements prominently displayed at a poster symposium. This event underscored the program's capacity to adjust to a rapidly changing educational landscape. The persistence of the pandemic in 2021 required a strategic shift to virtual platforms, enabling iCompBio to broaden its inclusivity and engage 15 students. This adaptation showcased the resilience and flexibility of both the participants and the program's framework, ensuring the continuity of high-quality research and engagement.

 

With the world adjusting to the aftermath of the pandemic in 2022, the iCompBio REU program introduced a hybrid model, training 14 students through a combination of in-person and remote interactions. This method facilitated a return to conventional practices while maintaining the adaptability developed in previous years. The program's ongoing emphasis on diversity and active participation further enriched the students' experience through enhanced mentorship, interdisciplinary collaboration, and access to cutting-edge research.

 

In 2023, the program built upon its previous accomplishments by training an additional 12 students, with a renewed focus on deepening their understanding of computational biology, honing critical research skills, and nurturing a spirit of collaboration.

 

Reflecting on the journey from 2019 to 2023, the iCompBio REU program's narrative is one of overcoming challenges, embracing innovation, and celebrating achievements. By training over 50 students, the program has made substantial contributions to the field of computational biology and played a crucial role in preparing the next generation of researchers. ICompBio’s steadfast dedication to diversity, educational excellence, and research integrity serves as a model for similar initiatives.
